questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent retrosternal pain for the past 3 months. She is currently asymptomatic. The episodes occur 2–3 times a week typically when she exerts herself or is outdoors during cold weather and have not increased in frequency or severity. The pain is “dull” and resolves when she stops or sits down for a while. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and right hip osteoarthritis. Her left leg was amputated below the knee after a motorcycle accident 25 years ago. She is not able to perform household chores because of hip pain. Medications include captopril, glyburide, and ibuprofen. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 144/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with no signs of ischemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography or cardiac stress testing is indicated for a patient with stable chest pain and an intermediate to high PTP of CAD. In patients with limited exercise capacity such as those who are frail or have an orthopedic disability, severe obesity (BMI > 40 kg/m2), COPD, or peripheral artery disease, pharmacological stress testing is the preferred option for stress testing. A substance that simulates the effect of exercise on the myocardium, i.e., dobutamine or a vasodilator (e.g., dipyridamole) is used in combination with cardiac imaging and ECG monitoring to detect evidence of stress-induced ischemic changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is performed in patients with gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) who have red flags (e.g., signs of gastrointestinal bleeding, unintentional weight loss, dysphagia) or risk factors for Barrett esophagus (e.g., male sex, age ≥ 50 years), and in those whose symptoms do not improve after a trial of proton pump inhibitor therapy. While GERD can cause retrosternal chest pain, the chest pain due to GERD is unrelated to exertion and is typically described as burning rather than dull.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is indicated for patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), i.e., STEMI, NSTEMI, or unstable angina. ACS is extremely unlikely in the absence of acute chest pain or chest pain equivalents, change in the characteristic of stable chest pain, or ischemic changes on ECG (e.g., ST elevation, ST depressions, T-wave inversions, new-onset bundle branch block).

In the workup of stable CAD, cardiac catheterization is only indicated for patients who have abnormal findings on noninvasive testing, contraindications for noninvasive testing, high suspicion of CAD and ambiguous results on noninvasive testing, or persistent or worsening symptoms despite appropriate therapy. A less invasive procedure should be considered first.

D) INCORRECT:

In the management of aortic valvular disease (e.g., aortic stenosis) or thoracic aortic disease (e.g., aortic dissection, aortic aneurysm), transesophageal echocardiography is used when the initial workup is inconclusive or for intraoperative planning. While chest pain due to aortic stenosis can be related to exertion, chest pain due to thoracic aortic disease is typically constant. In hemodynamically stable patients, the appropriate initial diagnostic studies are transthoracic echocardiography for aortic valvular disease and computed tomography with angiography for thoracic aortic disease.

E) INCORRECT:

An exercise stress test such as the treadmill stress test can be performed to evaluate patients with stable cardiac chest pain and an intermediate to high pretest probability of CAD but the patient must be able to achieve ≥ 5 metabolic equivalents of exercise or 85% of the predicted maximum heart rate (220 - age) using the chosen exercise modality. This patient's ability to achieve this target using a treadmill is limited by her severe hip osteoarthritis and lower limb amputation. Exercise stress testing can be performed in patients with disabilities using different modalities (e.g., handcycling).
questions.hint: Episodic retrosternal chest pain that is related to exertion and relieved with rest is consistent with cardiac chest pain due to stable coronary artery disease (CAD). Stable chest pain in women ≥ 60 years or men ≥ 40 years of age with additional risk factors for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) indicates an intermediate to high pretest probability (PTP) of CAD.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of nausea and abdominal discomfort for the past 4 months. The discomfort is located in the upper abdomen and sometimes occurs after eating, especially after a large meal. He has tried going for a walk after dinner to help with digestion, but his complaints have only increased. He has also experienced these symptoms while climbing the stairs to his apartment. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and stage 2 peripheral arterial disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. He drinks one to two beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 126 kg (278 lb); BMI is 45 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly. Foot pulses are absent bilaterally. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Abdominal ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen is used during the workup of pancreatitis and intestinal ischemia. This patient's recurrent abdominal discomfort and nausea following meals are characteristic of both of these diagnoses. However, pancreatitis classically causes pain that radiates to the patient's back, which is not seen here. In addition, this patient does not display other characteristic symptoms of chronic intestinal ischemia, such as abdominal bloating, food aversion, and weight loss. Moreover, worsening of symptoms with physical activity, as seen in this patient, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the abdomen may be used to diagnose intestinal ischemia. While recurrent abdominal discomfort and nausea following meals may be present in patients with chronic intestinal ischemia, other associated symptoms such as abdominal bloating, food aversion, and weight loss, which are not seen here, would also be expected. Moreover, worsening of symptoms with physical activity, as seen in this patient, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

A hydrogen breath test is used to diagnose lactose malabsorption, as hydrogen is released during bacterial fermentation of undigested lactose in the large intestine. Lactose intolerance manifests with abdominal discomfort following meals, as seen in this patient, but is also characterized by diarrhea and flatulence, which are absent here. Moreover, lactose intolerance is not exacerbated by physical activity.

D) CORRECT:

A cardiac stress test is typically performed to evaluate blood pressure, heart rate, and electrical conduction of the heart (using ECG) while the patient exercises under controlled conditions (usually on a treadmill) or after administration of a pharmacological agent to simulate cardiac stress (e.g., adenosine). Given his past medical history (stage 2 peripheral arterial disease) and 45 pack-years of smoking, this patient most likely has coronary heart disease. Coronary heart disease can manifest with gastrointestinal discomfort in the absence of retrosternal pain, especially in older individuals with diabetes mellitus. As in this patient, a resting ECG may not show evidence of cardiac ischemia. However, this patient is likely to have an abnormal result on cardiac stress testing (e.g., ST depressions), secondary to inadequate coronary artery perfusion.

In addition to cardiac workup, this patient should also undergo endoscopic evaluation via esophagogastroduodenoscopy as abdominal discomfort and nausea can also be caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease and he has multiple risk factors for Barrett esophagus (male sex, age, obesity, smoking).

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant is used to screen for pathologies involving the gallbladder and liver. Nausea and abdominal discomfort following meals may be present in cholecystitis; however, as this patient's symptoms are associated with exercise and many risk factors for atherosclerosis are present, another diagnostic study is warranted.

F) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is recommended as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for choledocholithiasis. Although choledocholithiasis may manifest with features such as abdominal pain and nausea, this patient's symptoms are associated with exercise and many risk factors for atherosclerosis are present, making a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: The patient’s 4-month history of nausea and abdominal discomfort that is exacerbated by large meals and exercise is consistent with atypical chest pain. In addition, the patient’s history of smoking, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obesity, and peripheral arterial disease suggests atherosclerosis as the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent retrosternal chest pain and tightness on exertion. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis of the right hip, and hypertension. Current medications include insulin, ibuprofen, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. His troponin level is within the reference range. An ECG at rest shows a right bundle branch block and infrequent premature ventricular contractions. The patient's symptoms are reproduced during adenosine stress testing. Repeat ECG during stress testing shows new ST depression of > 1 mm in leads V2, V3, and V4. Which of the following is the most important underlying mechanism of this patient's ECG changes?

choices.text: Ruptured cholesterol plaque within a coronary vessel
Diversion of blood flow from stenotic coronary arteries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vasospasm of the coronary arteries can cause the ECG changes seen in this patient. However, this is unlikely to occur in an adenosine stress test, as adenosine causes vasodilation. Coronary artery vasospasm is the pathophysiology behind Prinzmetal angina and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

A ruptured cholesterol plaque within a coronary vessel would cause acute myocardial infarction. While there is a risk for cardiac infarction with every stress test, it is considerably lower with an adenosine stress test than with the cardiac exercise stress test or dobutamine stress test. A different mechanism is more likely to have provoked this patient's ECG changes.

C) CORRECT:

Coronary steal syndrome is myocardial ischemia caused by the redistribution of blood flow. The rigidity of severely stenotic arteries allows only a low coronary flow reserve. When coronary arteries dilate, blood is therefore diverted to healthier vessels and collaterals. Adenosine simulates stress by causing coronary vasodilation via the activation of adenosine A2A receptors. This leads to tissue ischemia distal to the stenosed coronary artery, manifesting as new ECG changes. As soon as the patient experiences chest pain and/or ST elevations are seen, the stress test should be terminated.

Dipyridamole is another vasodilator that can be used during pharmacological stress tests to simulate the effect of exercise on the myocardium.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenosine can cause a transient atrioventricular (AV) nodal blockade and is in fact used for this purpose to treat patients with a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). However, ECG findings in this patient are not consistent with an AV nodal block.

E) INCORRECT:

Adenosine has only a minor effect on the left ventricular preload and this would not be enough to cause the ECG changes seen in this patient, which are a sign of impaired myocardial perfusion. Instead, adenosine predominantly affects coronary vessels and vessels responsible for afterload.

F) INCORRECT:

Adenosine causes dilation of the coronary arteries and has antiadrenergic effects on the myocardium. This mechanism is different than those used in the exercise stress test and dobutamine stress test, which both increase myocardial demand. Thus, increased myocardial oxygen demand does not play a key role in ischemia and subsequent ECG changes.
questions.hint: This patient underwent adenosine stress testing for evaluation of suspected coronary artery disease. The results of his pharmacological stress test are consistent with decreased blood flow in the anteroseptal region.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurring chest discomfort. The symptoms occur when walking up the stairs to her apartment or when walking quickly for 5 minutes on level terrain. She has not had shortness of breath, palpitations, or dizziness. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include estrogen replacement therapy, metoprolol, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and rosuvastatin. She drinks 3–4 cups of coffee per day. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her pulse is 65/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A resting ECG shows normal sinus rhythm and the results of routine serum studies show no abnormalities. She is scheduled for a cardiac exercise stress test in 2 days. Which of the following is most appropriate to discontinue before the procedure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Estrogen-containing oral contraceptive pills have high doses of estrogen and are contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) but the effects of postmenopausal estrogen replacement therapy on the risk of CAD are less clear. In any case, the data on the effects of estrogen on cardiac exercise stress testing is inconclusive, and withholding estrogen therapy before cardiac stress testing is not currently a recommendation.

B) CORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol) and calcium channel blockers (CCBs), especially the nondihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., verapamil), can affect the diagnostic value of cardiac exercise stress testing because they attenuate the chronotropic and inotropic effects of exercise. These medications may be withheld prior to testing at the clinician's discretion.

Methylxanthines (e.g., caffeine, theophylline) are competitive inhibitors of adenosine receptors and increase the risk of arrhythmias, which can hinder cardiac stress test completion or result interpretation. Discontinuation of methylxanthines should be considered also because the exercise stress test may need to be converted to a pharmacological stress test if the patient is unable to achieve a target heart rate with exercise. Methylxanthines decrease coronary vasodilation and thereby interfere with a pharmacological stress test using vasodilator agents (e.g., adenosine, dipyridamole).

C) INCORRECT:

Statins (e.g., rosuvastatin) do not interfere with a cardiac stress test. Patients without electrolyte abnormalities can also continue to take diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) before cardiac stress testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Statins (e.g., rosuvastatin) do not interfere with cardiac stress testing.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) do not interfere significantly with cardiac stress testing. Estrogen-containing oral contraceptive pills have high doses of estrogen and are contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) but the effects of postmenopausal estrogen replacement therapy on the risk of CAD are less clear. In any case, the data on the effects of estrogen on cardiac exercise stress testing is inconclusive, and withholding estrogen therapy before cardiac stress testing is not currently a recommendation.

F) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) and diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) do not interfere significantly with cardiac stress testing. Patients without electrolyte abnormalities can continue to take them before testing.
questions.hint: The goal of cardiac stress testing is to evaluate for stress-induced ischemic changes on ECG and/or imaging. The stress is created by increasing heart rate and contractility (using exercise or dobutamine) or by inducing a coronary steal phenomenon (using vasodilators). Certain medications or substances may have to be withheld prior to testing in order to obtain reliable results.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of episodic stabbing chest pain. She currently feels well. The pain is unrelated to exercise or rest and does not radiate. The episodes typically last less than 15 minutes and lead to feelings of anxiety. She has not had dyspnea, cough, or lightheadedness. She has no history of serious illness. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. At this visit, which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for coronary artery disease in this patient?

choices.text: No further testing at this visit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is an alternative to cardiac stress testing in patients with intermediate or high PTP of CAD. As this patient has a low PTP of CAD, a reasonable option is to obtain a coronary artery calcium score, which is done using cardiac CT without contrast rather than CCTA.

B) INCORRECT:

Nuclear myocardial perfusion imaging (e.g., positron emission tomography, single-photon emission computed tomography) is an option for cardiac stress testing in patients with an intermediate or high PTP of CAD. Although nuclear exercise stress testing is not indicated for this patient with a low PTP of CAD, exercise stress testing with a different modality may be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Troponin I is elevated in acute myocardial infarction and is therefore useful in the workup of suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS). In this patient, the absence of acute chest pain and signs of ischemia on ECG makes ACS unlikely. Troponin I is, therefore, likely to be negative and of little value in patients with suspected stable CAD.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with a low PTP of CAD, a shared decision-making approach that takes patient preferences, cost, and available resources at the setting of the care into consideration is recommended. Deferring testing for CAD (because patients at low risk may have false-positive results) and initiating a workup for other causes of chest pain is an appropriate step. Exercise ECG testing or coronary artery calcium scoring (using a non-contrast cardiac CT) may be reasonable alternative options in select patients. Cardiac stress testing with imaging or pharmacological stress is not required for patients with a low PTP of CAD.

E) INCORRECT:

A pharmacological cardiac stress test (e.g., regadenoson cardiac MRI) is an option for cardiac stress testing in patients with an intermediate or high PTP of CAD. This patient has a low PTP of CAD.

F) INCORRECT:

A pharmacological cardiac stress test (e.g., dobutamine stress echocardiography) is an option for cardiac stress testing in patients with an intermediate or high PTP of CAD. This patient has a low PTP of CAD.
questions.hint: Episodic chest pain that is unrelated to exertion, not increasing in frequency, and described as “stabbing” is consistent with possible cardiac chest pain due to stable coronary artery disease (CAD). However, stable chest pain in women < 60 years or men < 40 years of age without additional risk factors or concerning findings on the initial ECG indicates low pretest probability (PTP) of CAD.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with angina pectoris comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of shortness of breath on exertion that improves with rest. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, and nitroglycerine. Echocardiography shows left ventricular septal and apical hypokinesis. Cardiac catheterization shows 96% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. The patient undergoes angioplasty and placement of a stent. The patient's shortness of breath subsequently resolves and follow-up echocardiography one week later shows normal regional contractile function. Which of the following is the most accurate explanation for the changes in echocardiography?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unstable angina pectoris is characterized by the sudden new onset of symptoms of acute coronary syndrome at rest or on minimal exertion, or rapidly worsening symptoms (crescendo angina). However, this patient has long-standing dyspnea, which likely occurs on exertion and improves with rest and would therefore be most consistent with stable angina pectoris.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo cardiomyopathy) describes an acute decline in left-ventricular function following an emotionally or physically stressful event (e.g., unexpected death of a relative, natural disaster, or respiratory failure, infection). Although dyspnea can be present, it would not be limited to exertion, as in this patient. A hallmark finding on echocardiography is apical ballooning of the left ventricle, which is not seen here. In contrast to this patient who experienced rapid symptom relief and functional improvement after revascularization, patients with stress cardiomyopathy recover spontaneously and only require symptomatic treatment with beta blockers or ACE inhibitors.

C) CORRECT:

Hibernating myocardium is characterized by persistently impaired myocardial contractility at rest (on echocardiography or radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging) that is partially or completely reversible when adequate oxygen supply is restored (e.g., after angioplasty or coronary artery bypass surgery). In response to decreased perfusion, hibernating myocardial cells enter a state of decreased metabolic activity. In contrast, myocardial stunning occurs after an episode of acute ischemia and is characterized by transiently impaired myocardial contractility.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial scar tissue indicates myocardial necrosis, most often induced by irreversible myocardial ischemia due to myocardial infarction (MI). The patient could have undergone a silent MI, but, since myocardial scars are marked by complete replacement with fibrous, non-contractile tissue, there would be permanent dyskinesia on echocardiography even after revascularization. Scar tissue can also lead to a true ventricular aneurysm, which would then manifest as an outward bulge of the affected segment during myocardial contraction.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac remodeling is a chronic process in which the myocardium undergoes permanent changes in structure (i.e., mass, shape, dimensions) and/or function to compensate for cardiac injury or an increased hemodynamic load that does not rapidly improve after treatment (here within one week). Reduced contractile function would likely persist even after successful revascularization.

F) INCORRECT:

In myocardial stunning, affected segments undergo short but significant acute ischemia ("stunning"), but regain their baseline contractile functionality because of the short-term nature of the event. This patient's myocardial dysfunction is similar in that function is regained after revascularization. However, this patient's symptoms suggest a prolonged, chronic history of myocardial flow reduction and ischemia.
questions.hint: The patient had signs and symptoms of chronic left ventricular dysfunction that were reversed by revascularization.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with stable coronary artery disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Aside from occasional exertional chest pain on mowing the lawn or prolonged jogging, he feels well. He goes jogging for 20 minutes once a week and takes a tablet of sublingual nitroglycerine prior to his run to prevent anginal chest pain. The patient would like to run longer distances and asks the physician whether he could increase the dose of the drug prior to running. Administration of higher dosages of this drug is most likely to result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rebound angina is the increase in anginal symptoms due to decreased drug levels during the nitrate-free intervals in intermittent therapy. It is usually associated with the use of transdermal nitroglycerin patches, not with sublingual administration. Moreover, this patient's once-weekly usage puts him at low risk for rebound angina.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrate tolerance often develops after 2–3 days of continuous administration and is more likely with high dosages and long-acting preparations. In order to minimize this side effect, daily nitrate-free intervals of at least 8 hours are recommended. Since this patient only has an estimated once-weekly usage with adequate medication-free intervals, a higher dosage will not increase his risk of developing tolerance.

C) CORRECT:

Low-dose nitrate improves myocardial perfusion primarily by acting as a venodilator that decreases ventricular wall tension via preload reduction. In addition, high-dose nitrate dilates coronary and peripheral arteries, thereby preventing coronary spasms and reducing ventricular afterload along with subsequent myocardial oxygen demand. However, peripheral arterial dilation also causes systemic hypotension, which induces a reflex sympathetic activity leading to tachycardia and increased myocardial contractility. As a result, myocardial oxygen demand paradoxically increases. Simultaneous administration of β-blockers has a synergetic anti-ischemic effect and can help prevent reflex tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Anaphylactic reactions occur in < 1% of patients treated with nitrates. Furthermore, this patient has been taking this drug regularly, making an allergic reaction to an increase in dosage unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitrates dilate coronary arteries and thus prevent rather than cause coronary artery spasms. Therefore, they are regularly used in the long-term treatment of Prinzmetal angina.

F) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of withdrawal can occur after abrupt cessation of use of an addictive recreational or therapeutic substance. Nitrates are not known to cause addiction.
questions.hint: Administration of metoprolol would help to counteract this adverse effect.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for treatment of unstable angina. Cardiac catheterization shows occlusion that has caused a 50% reduction in the diameter of the left circumflex artery. Resistance to blood flow in this vessel has increased by what factor relative to a vessel with no occlusion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the resistance to blood flow increases when the radius of the vessel decreases (by 50% in this case), this answer is incorrect.

B) CORRECT:

When the length of the vessel and viscosity of blood remain constant, the relationship between resistance and the radius of the vessel in the Poiseuille equation can be simplified to R ≈ 1/r4. The diameter (and thus the radius) of this patient's vessel has decreased by 50%. Therefore, R ∼ 1/(0.5 x r)4 → 1/(0.0625 x r4) → 1/0.0625 x 1/r4 → 16 x 1/r4. Thus, resistance to blood flow increases 16 times.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the resistance to blood flow increases when the radius of the vessel decreases (by 50% in this case), this answer is incorrect.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the resistance to blood flow increases when the radius of the vessel decreases (by 50% in this case), this answer is incorrect.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the resistance to blood flow increases when the radius of the vessel decreases (by 50% in this case), this answer is incorrect.

F) INCORRECT:

Although the resistance to blood flow increases when the radius of the vessel decreases (by 50% in this case), this answer is incorrect.
questions.hint: The corresponding increase in resistance to blood flow can be calculated by the Poiseuille equation: R = 8Lη/(πr4), where R = resistance to flow, L = length of the vessel, η = viscosity, and r = radius of the vessel.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no complaints and has no history of serious illness. He works as a forklift operator in a factory. His brother died of malignant melanoma. He smokes occasionally and drinks a glass of wine once a week. His pulse is 79/min and blood pressure is 129/84 mm Hg. Which of the following causes of death is this patient most at risk for over the next 15 years?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer is the second most common cancer among men as well as women and the leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide. Although this patient's occasional smoking slightly increases his risk of lung cancer-related death, his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

B) CORRECT:

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of death in the US and worldwide, and the death rate is higher in men than in women. This patient's risk for coronary heart disease is higher than a non-smoker due to his occasional smoking. Overall, malignancy is the most common cause of death among patients 45–64 years of age. However, heart disease is a more common cause of death than any single type of cancer in the United States.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant melanoma is a life-threatening dermatologic disease and the fifth most common cancer in men. While this patient's family history increases his risk of developing melanoma (around 10% of melanoma cases are familial), his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

D) INCORRECT:

Industrial accidents are the third most common cause of death in American men. Although this patient's occupation as a forklift operator increases his risk of accident-related injuries, his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer is the most common cause of cancer in men in the US and the second most common cause of cancer-related death. Although the fact that this patient is male means he is at risk of developing prostate cancer, his risk of death due to another cause is higher.

F) INCORRECT:

Suicide or intentional self-harm is currently the tenth leading cause of death in the US. This patient does not express any suicidal intention and has no signs of depression; his risk of death due to another cause is higher.
questions.hint: What is the leading cause of death in men in the United States?

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying a drug to treat refractory angina pectoris. The drug works by selectively inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes. At high doses, this drug also partially inhibits the degradation of fatty acids. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ranolazine increases oxygen efficiency in cardiomyocytes through two mechanisms. First, the drug decreases myocardial tension during diastole by impairing late phase sodium influx into cardiac myocytes, disrupting the sodium-calcium exchange mechanism and leading to reduced calcium flux and wall tension. Second, ranolazine causes cardiomyocytes to favor glycolysis over the beta-oxidation of fatty acids for energy generation. Because glycolysis is not dependent on oxygen availability and beta-oxidation is oxygen-intensive, this shift reduces the oxygen needs of cardiac tissue. Importantly, neither mechanism causes significant changes in the heart rate or blood pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased prolactin release can arise as a side effect of non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., verapamil). Hyperprolactinemia is thought to occur as a result of central inhibition of dopamine production, which ordinarily prevents the production of prolactin. While verapamil can effectively treat angina by decreasing heart rate and contractility, it does not affect fatty acid metabolism or selectively inhibit the late influx of sodium ions in cardiac myocytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased uric acid excretion can be a consequence of treatment with low-dose aspirin or niacin. Aspirin is prescribed to patients with angina as secondary prevention. However, aspirin tends to increase mitochondrial long-chain fatty acid oxidation, whereas the drug in question reduces it. Niacin is a lipid-lowering drug that is mainly used to treat hypertriglyceridemia, not for secondary prevention (statins are much more commonly used in this role). In addition, neither aspirin nor niacin directly treats anginal pain, and neither selectively inhibits sodium influx into cardiac myocytes.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased insulin release occurs as a consequence of medications that block the beta 2 adrenergic receptor. Drugs in this class, commonly known as beta blockers (e.g., propranolol), will also have an inhibitory effect on lipolysis as a result of beta receptor blockage on adipocytes. Beta blockers are very commonly used to treat angina. They do not, however, inhibit the late influx of sodium ions in cardiomyocytes.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased parasympathetic tone from the vagus nerve results in a reduced heart rate and is seen with digoxin administration. This drug inhibits the efflux of sodium ions from cardiomyocytes through the sodium-potassium pump. However, digoxin does not selectively inhibit the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes, and it has no effect on fatty acid metabolism. Digoxin is used to treat heart failure and atrial tachyarrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation and flutter), but it is not used to treat angina.
questions.hint: The drug in question is ranolazine.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension undergoes 99mTc cardiac scintigraphy for the evaluation of a 3-month history of retrosternal chest tightness on exertion. The patient's symptoms are reproduced following the administration of dipyridamole. A repeat ECG shows new ST depression and T wave inversion in leads V5 and V6. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's signs and symptoms during the procedure?

choices.text: Ruptured cholesterol plaque within a coronary vessel

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vasospasm of coronary arteries, which is the cause of Prinzmetal angina, would lead to recurrent episodes of chest tightness and the ECG changes seen in this patient. However, patients with Prinzmetal angina typically develop symptoms at rest, unlike this patient who reported chest tightness on exertion. The onset of chest pain after the administration of dipyridamole, which induces vasodilation rather than vasospasm, suggests a different cause for this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular preload is decreased by venous vasodilators (e.g., nitroglycerin) and by hypovolemia. Dipyridamole can decrease left ventricular afterload by inducing vasodilation of peripheral arteries but it does not significantly alter left ventricular preload.

C) CORRECT:

Dipyridamole increases adenosine levels, which, in turn, causes coronary vasodilation via the activation of adenosine A2A receptors. Coronary steal syndrome is myocardial ischemia caused by redistribution of blood flow. The rigidity of severely stenotic arteries allows only a low coronary flow reserve. When coronary arteries dilate, blood is, therefore, diverted to healthier vessels and collaterals. This leads to tissue ischemia distal to the stenosis in the coronary artery, which manifests as chest tightness and new ECG changes. This phenomenon is the underlying principle of the adenosine or dipyridamole pharmacological stress test.

In the case of a cardiac exercise stress test or a dobutamine stress test, cardiac ischemia is reproduced by increasing heart rate and contractility, which, in turn, increases myocardial oxygen demand. The stress test should be terminated as soon as the patient experiences chest pain and/or ST elevations.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of a coronary vessel following the rupture of a cholesterol plaque is the process that underlies acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which would cause chest tightness and the ECG changes seen here. While there is a risk for ACS with every stress test, it is low with a dipyridamole stress test because dipyridamole inhibits platelet aggregation. A different mechanism is more likely to have provoked this patient's chest tightness.

E) INCORRECT:

Myocardial oxygen demand (MVO2) is increased during the dobutamine stress test and cardiac exercise stress test. Dipyridamole alters coronary perfusion and affects myocardial oxygen supply but it does not significantly alter MVO2.
questions.hint: This patient underwent dipyridamole stress testing for evaluation of suspected coronary artery disease. The results of her pharmacologic stress test are consistent with decreased blood flow in the anterolateral region. In addition to being a platelet phosphodiesterase inhibitor, dipyridamole prevents the breakdown of adenosine by inhibiting adenosine deaminase.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of chest pain. The pain is episodic and lasts for 5–10 minutes before it subsides spontaneously; it is localized to the left side of the chest and does not radiate. The patient reports that the pain typically occurs when he is angry or upset. He has not noticed any changes in the pattern, intensity, or duration of pain during these episodes. He does not report any other symptoms and there is no chest pain at the time of presentation. The patient has a history of asthma and hypertension. His medications are albuterol as needed and amlodipine. He goes swimming once a week and tries to maintain a healthy diet. He drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a point of maximal impulse in the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Auscultation shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. An ECG shows a sinus rhythm and no abnormalities. At this visit, which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for coronary artery disease in this patient?

choices.text: No further testing at this visit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deferring testing for CAD and initiating a workup for other causes of chest pain is an appropriate step in patients with a low PTP of CAD because patients at low risk may have false-positive results. This patient has an intermediate to high PTP of CAD and requires further testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Troponin (e.g., troponin T) concentrations are measured for the workup of a suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and would be increased in patients with acute myocardial infarction (NSTEMI or STEMI). ACS is extremely unlikely in the absence of acute chest pain or acute chest pain equivalents, change in the characteristic of cardiac chest pain, or new-onset ischemic changes on ECG (e.g., ST elevation, new LBBB, ST depressions, T-wave inversions). Instead, the presentation is more consistent with stable CAD, in which troponin T concentration is of little value in the diagnostic workup.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress testing using adenosine or dipyridamole is contraindicated in patients with reactive airway disease such as asthma because of possible bronchospasm. If pharmacological stress testing is considered, dobutamine should be considered for cardiac stress induction.

D) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery calcium (CAC) scoring using a noncontrast cardiac CT is an appropriate step for risk stratification in patients with a low PTP of CAD. This patient has an intermediate to high PTP of CAD and requires a different test.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with stable chest pain and an intermediate to high PTP of CAD should undergo coronary CT angiography (CCTA) or cardiac stress testing (CST) for further risk stratification and treatment decisions. The goal of CST is to evaluate for stress-induced ischemic changes on ECG or cardiac imaging (stress echocardiography, myocardial perfusion imaging, or cardiac MRI). The stress is created by increasing heart rate and contractility (using exercise or dobutamine) or by inducing a coronary steal phenomenon (using vasodilators such as adenosine or dipyridamole). Reactive airway disease (e.g., asthma) is a contraindication for stress testing using adenosine or dipyridamole.
questions.hint: This patient likely has stable cardiac chest pain (episodic; triggered by stress; no change in pattern, intensity, or duration). Stable chest pain in women ≥ 60 years or men ≥ 40 years of age with additional risk factors for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (e.g., hypertension) indicates an intermediate to high pretest probability (PTP) of coronary artery disease (CAD).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of intermittent left-sided chest pain. He says that the pain feels “like something is crushing” his chest and is sometimes associated with shortness of breath. The pain occurs when he climbs more than 2 flights of stairs and improves with rest. He has hypertension treated with valsartan. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Pulse is 80/min and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation discloses normal heart sounds; there are no murmurs or rubs. A cardiac exercise stress test reproduces the patient's symptoms and is stopped after 5 minutes. ECG during the stress test shows sinus tachycardia and ST depressions in leads II and III. Which of the following is most appropriate to improve this patient's exercise tolerance in the long term?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1, which results in the inhibition of platelet aggregation. Antiplatelet therapy reduces the risk of complications of stable angina (e.g., myocardial infarction) and is indicated for all patients with ischemic heart disease who do not have specific contraindications to antiplatelet drugs. However, aspirin therapy does not improve exercise tolerance or reduce anginal pain in patients with stable angina.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is usually performed for the emergency diagnosis and treatment of acute coronary syndrome. In stable angina, as seen here, PCI is only indicated if there are activity-limiting symptoms despite optimal medical therapy, contraindications to medical therapy, or stenosis of multiple or critical coronary arteries (e.g., left coronary artery), none of which is present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil causes coronary and peripheral vasodilation and reduces cardiac contractility, which reduces myocardial oxygen demand. Therefore, it can reduce anginal symptoms in patients with stable ischemic heart disease, which is seen here. However, calcium channel blockers are considered a second-line therapy for the treatment of stable angina.

D) CORRECT:

Atenolol is a β1-selective adrenergic receptor blocker used as first-line therapy to improve exercise tolerance and reduce the frequency of anginal episodes in patients with stable CAD. Like other β-blockers, atenolol relieves anginal pain by decreasing heart rate and cardiac contractility, which reduces myocardial oxygen demand. Although β-blockers also inhibit adrenergic-mediated coronary vasodilation, the resulting increase in coronary vascular resistance is overcome by the reduction in heart rate, which improves coronary perfusion by prolonging diastole. In addition to pharmacotherapy (which includes antiplatelet therapy, lipid-lowering therapy, and management of hypertension and diabetes), risk-reducing strategies (secondary prevention of CAD) include weight loss, smoking cessation, and aerobic exercise.

Calcium channel blockers, long-acting nitrates (e.g., isosorbide mononitrate), and ranolazine are alternative antianginal agents if there are contraindications to β-blockers or β-blockers do not provide adequate symptom control.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin is a short-acting nitrate that dilates the coronary vasculature and decreases left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (preload) to improve coronary perfusion and reduce myocardial oxygen demand. Therefore, it can reduce anginal symptoms in patients with stable ischemic heart disease. Although nitroglycerin is a first-line therapy for the relief of acute anginal symptoms, it does not improve long-term exercise tolerance.
questions.hint: This patient, who has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (male gender, age ≥ 45 years, hypertension, smoking, overweight), has exertional chest pain and ST segment changes during stress testing. This is consistent with a diagnosis of stable angina due to underlying coronary artery disease (CAD).

questions.text:
A physically active 57-year-old woman reports one week of intermittent, intense, sharp retrosternal chest pain that extends to her neck. The pain is sometimes associated with nausea and is not temporally associated with eating meals. It can occur both at rest and on exertion and has wakened her from sleep on several occasions.
The patient smokes and has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and heartburn. Years ago, she developed hives and lip swelling while undergoing intravenous pyelography. Her current medications are aspirin, amlodipine, metformin, and famotidine. Recent financial difficulties have caused her considerable stress.
Her BMI is 31, her blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 76 beats per minute. She has no jugular venous distention or edema, and she has clear lungs and normal heart sounds. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. She has no lower-extremity arthritis and walks normally.
Electrocardiography is performed when the patient is asymptomatic (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Dobutamine stress test with nuclear imaging

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exercise treadmill testing with electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring is the initial diagnostic test of choice in patients who have an intermediate pretest probability of CAD, are able to exercise, and have no baseline ECG abnormalities (such as preexcitation, ventricular-paced rhythm, ST-segment depressions with or without left ventricular hypertrophy, and left bundle-branch block).

B) INCORRECT:

A pharmacologic stress test (e.g., with dobutamine) is recommended for unstable patients, patients who are unable to exercise, patients with aortic stenosis, and patients with ECG evidence of left bundle-branch block.

C) INCORRECT:

A pharmacologic stress test (e.g., with dobutamine) is recommended for unstable patients, patients who are unable to exercise, patients with aortic stenosis, and patients with ECG evidence of left bundle-branch block.

D) CORRECT:

Women are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease after menopause. Chest pain in a postmenopausal woman with multiple cardiac risk factors raises concern for underlying obstructive coronary artery disease (CAD) and warrants further diagnostic testing.

Compared to men, women with CAD often present at an older age, with more comorbidities, and with a greater mix of atypical and typical symptoms. Women are more likely to characterize their pain as intense and sharp; as involving the shoulder, arm, or neck; and as being accompanied by nausea, palpitations, and fatigue. Symptoms often occur at rest, during sleep, and at times of psychological stress.

An ECG pattern of left ventricular hypertrophy with strain, as this patient has, warrants exercise stress testing with an imaging modality, such as echocardiography.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for a postmenopausal woman with atypical chest pain whose resting electrocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy with strain is exercise stress testing with an imaging modality, such as echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography is an alternative approach to excluding CAD in patients with atypical chest pain, but it exposes the patient to radiation and a radiographic contrast agent. Given this patient’s history of contrast allergy, coronary CT is not the best initial test.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman with no known medical problems reports a 6-month history of exertional chest discomfort. She has not had pain at rest or an increase in the frequency or severity of her exertional discomfort.
She is referred for exercise radionuclide perfusion imaging and completes 8 minutes on the treadmill (9 metabolic equivalents of work). The test is terminated for chest pain, and perfusion images reveal a small, mild defect in the inferolateral wall with stress that resolves at rest, consistent with inducible ischemia.
The patient has a resting blood pressure of 155/90 mm Hg, a heart rate of 76 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 100% while breathing ambient air. Her physical examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram identifies normal sinus rhythm.
In addition to aspirin and statin therapy, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Surveillance with annual stress perfusion imaging
Cardiac catheterization with diagnostic coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The need for additional stress perfusion imaging studies should be guided by changes in symptoms. Routine annual or surveillance stress testing is inappropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with stable angina and an abnormal stress test that indicates low cardiovascular risk (in this case, myocardial ischemia at a high workload and small reversible defect) usually have a favorable prognosis. When treated medically, these patients typically have outcomes similar to those of patients who undergo revascularization.

Medical management is generally considered the most appropriate initial approach for patients with low-risk cardiovascular disease. They should be offered a trial of medical therapy — with aspirin plus at least one of the following: a beta-blocker, calcium-channel blocker, and/or long-acting nitrate — before cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography. Intensive statin therapy should also be initiated.

Key learning point: For a patient with stable angina and an abnormal stress test that indicates low cardiovascular risk, the most appropriate management consists of aspirin, a statin, and at least one of the following: a beta-blocker, a calcium-channel blocker, and/or a long-acting nitrate.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent referral for cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is appropriate for a patient with resting or progressive angina. Elective angiography is reasonable for patients with stable angina who have symptoms despite adequate medical therapy, who are unable to tolerate medical therapy, or who have high-risk findings (e.g., ischemia at a low workload or a large, reversible anterior-wall defect), as these patients may be candidates for invasive reperfusion strategies, such as percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting.

D) INCORRECT:

Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is indicated for acute coronary syndromes or after percutaneous coronary intervention. This patient should receive daily low-dose aspirin for secondary prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography is unlikely to add further prognostic information in a patient with typical exertional angina and a stress test that indicates low cardiovascular risk.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia and gout presents with exertional chest pressure. He had a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction 6 years ago, when an angiogram showed a severe culprit left circumflex stenosis, for which he received a drug-eluting stent, and a moderate stenosis in the mid-right coronary artery, which did not warrant intervention.
The patient walks three miles daily, but that activity can be limited by exertional chest discomfort. The discomfort has been stable for several years, is predictable, and is promptly relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin.
A recent exercise nuclear stress test showed a normal exercise capacity of 12 metabolic equivalents, normal left ventricular systolic function, and a mild inferior-wall reversible perfusion defect.
The patient’s current medications include aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg daily, long-acting metoprolol 400 mg daily, and 0.4 mg sublingual nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain.
His current blood pressure is 128/79 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 70 beats per minute. His physical examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with no ischemic changes.
Which one of the following changes should be made to this patient's medication regimen to help improve his symptoms?

choices.text: Start coenzyme Q10 60 mg once daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coenzyme Q10 is not a recommended treatment for stable angina.

B) CORRECT:

A beta-blocker (if not contraindicated) is recommended as therapy for chronic stable angina, also known as symptomatic stable ischemic heart disease. If a beta-blocker at maximal dose does not alleviate anginal symptoms, then additional anti-anginal therapy should be added with either a long-acting nitrate (e.g., isosorbide mononitrate) or a calcium-channel blocker.

The choice of calcium-channel blocker depends on what other agents the patient is taking. In patients taking a beta-blocker, such as this patient, a dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker (such as amlodipine or extended-release nifedipine) is preferred. Short-acting nifedipine should be avoided because of the risk of reflex tachycardia. Dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers are less likely than other calcium-channel blockers to lead to bradycardia or conduction abnormalities when used in combination with a beta-blocker. On the other hand, if the patient is not taking a beta-blocker (usually due to contraindications or intolerance to beta-blockers), nondihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers such as diltiazem or verapamil are used. These will help control the patient’s heart rate and can be safely combined with nitrates.

The primary purpose of adding an antianginal agent (beta-blocker or calcium-channel blocker) in this scenario is not to reduce blood pressure (BP) but rather to reduce cardiac workload, thus reducing angina symptoms. Such a reduction can be achieved by adding these agents even when the BP is already controlled, as in this case. If the BP was low or low-normal, then one would need to exercise caution when adding these agents so as to avoid hypotension and orthostasis; that is not the case here.

A short-acting nitrate (sublingual or spray) should be used for immediate relief of angina.

Key learning point: For a patient whose angina is not relieved by beta-blocker therapy at maximal dose, one of these two medications should be added: a calcium-channel blocker or a long-acting nitrate.

C) INCORRECT:

Ranolazine should be reserved for patients with angina refractory to conventional medical therapy. A therapeutic trial with a calcium-channel blocker or a long-acting nitrate is appropriate before using ranolazine.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that increasing the dose of aspirin improves angina symptoms; however, aspirin is important for this patient to continue, given his coronary artery disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, such as lisinopril, have proven benefit in patients with acute myocardial infarction, depressed ejection fraction, cardiomyopathy, or diabetic nephropathy. Lisinopril has no proven benefit in patients with stable angina and is therefore not indicated in this patient.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man with documented coronary artery disease presents with persistent but stable exertional angina despite treatment with atorvastatin and aspirin. The patient’s current blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg, his heart rate is 80 beats per minute with regular rhythm, and his fasting LDL cholesterol level is 65 mg/dL (reference range, <130).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors (such as lisinopril) and angiotensin-receptor blockers (such as candesartan) are useful adjunctive therapies in patients with coronary disease who have hypertension or left ventricular dysfunction, but they are not anti-anginal agents. Whether they reduce the incidence of myocardial infarction independent of their blood-pressure-lowering effects is controversial.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-acting nitrates (such as isosorbide mononitrate, but not the immediate-release nitrate isosorbide dinitrate) and calcium-channel blockers (such as diltiazem) can be considered initially or added if a beta-blocker does not sufficiently control the angina.

C) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors (such as lisinopril) and angiotensin-receptor blockers (such as candesartan) are useful adjunctive therapies in patients with coronary disease who have hypertension or left ventricular dysfunction, but they are not anti-anginal agents. Whether they reduce the incidence of myocardial infarction independent of their blood-pressure-lowering effects is controversial.

D) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel is an antiplatelet agent and does not have antianginal properties.

E) CORRECT:

A beta-blocker is one of the first-line therapeutic agents for patients with symptomatic coronary artery disease, especially those with concomitant hypertension. Beta-blockers reduce myocardial oxygen demand by decreasing blood pressure, heart rate, and myocardial contractility.

Key learning point: In addition to aspirin and a statin, the type of medication routinely recommended for a patient with symptomatic coronary artery disease is a beta-blocker.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia reports an 8-month history of chest pressure and left-arm pain that occur only during substantial physical activity and that always resolve quickly with rest. Her current medications are pravastatin, amlodipine, and aspirin.
Her physical examination is normal, with no jugular venous distention, murmurs or gallops, or peripheral edema.
Her 12-lead electrocardiogram is normal. She has no ischemic electrocardiographic changes on an exercise test (11 minutes on a standard Bruce protocol), but nuclear imaging shows a moderate-size, reversible area of hypoperfusion in the distribution of the distal right coronary artery.
In addition to starting guideline-directed medical therapy, which one of the following additional investigations, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography is reasonable for symptomatic patients who are at intermediate risk for CAD, including patients with equivocal stress-test results and those with known or suspected coronary anomalies. It would not change management for this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with stable angina are considered to be low-risk if their exercise capacity is good and imaging does not identify features of left-main or multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD). Low-risk patients are best managed with optimal medical therapy (aspirin, a statin, and anti-ischemic medications [i.e., beta-blockers, calcium-channel blockers, and nitrates]); they do not need further investigation. In the landmark COURAGE trial, conducted among patients with stable CAD, percutaneous coronary intervention did not lower rates of death or myocardial infarction when added to optimal medical therapy. The more recent ISCHEMIA trial further failed to demonstrate a benefit of invasive interventions for stable CAD even in those with moderate-to-severe ischemia on stress testing.

Key learning point: Patients with low-risk stable angina are best managed with optimal medical therapy and do not require further investigation.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is recommended for stable CAD if symptoms interfere with lifestyle despite optimal medical therapy or if a stress test identifies high-risk findings (e.g., low exercise tolerance, electrocardiographic or imaging findings suggesting left-main or 3-vessel CAD).

D) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine echocardiography, a form of pharmacologic stress testing with echocardiographic imaging during rest and stress, is indicated in a patient who cannot exercise. Otherwise, exercise is the preferred stressor for stress testing. Echocardiography is preferred over nuclear imaging when dyspnea prompts the stress testing, because the patient’s diastolic left ventricular function, valvular abnormalities, and right ventricular function and pressures can be assessed.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary calcium scoring is generally performed to estimate the risk for CAD in an asymptomatic person. It adds no useful information in a symptomatic patient with imaging abnormalities on stress testing.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery bypass grafting 6 years ago reports a 6-month history of chronic stable angina. His symptoms occur after walking about four blocks on flat ground or climbing one flight of stairs. His current medications are metoprolol 200 mg twice daily, aspirin, atorvastatin, metformin, and isosorbide mononitrate 120 mg once daily.
Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography demonstrates a patent coronary graft and occlusion of a small branch of the left circumflex artery that is not amenable to percutaneous coronary intervention.
His heart rate is 58 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 104/58 mm Hg.
What is the most appropriate therapy to manage this patient’s angina?

choices.text: Increase the dose of isosorbide mononitrate

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ranolazine, an inhibitor of myocyte sodium channels, prevents cellular calcium overload, reduces diastolic wall tension, and improves oxygen supply-demand mismatch — thereby improving angina. Ranolazine has minimal effects on blood pressure and heart rate. In a patient with chronic stable angina who is receiving maximal doses of routine antianginal medications or whose low blood pressure and heart rate prevent the safe uptitration of other antianginal agents, ranolazine is the therapy of choice.

Key learning point: The medication that is most appropriate for a patient with refractory, low-level, chronic stable angina whose heart rate and blood pressure are low-normal while taking appropriate doses of a beta-blocker and a nitrate is ranolazine.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem and amlodipine) and nitrates are also effective antianginal therapies that can be initiated or uptitrated. However, none of these options is appropriate in a patient who is already receiving recommended maximal doses of beta-blocker and nitrate therapy and who has a low-normal blood pressure and heart rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Increasing beta-blocker (metoprolol) therapy to reduce heart rate is often effective in reducing anginal episodes. However, none of these options is appropriate in a patient who is already receiving recommended maximal doses of beta-blocker and nitrate therapy and who has a low-normal blood pressure and heart rate.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem and amlodipine) and nitrates are also effective antianginal therapies that can be initiated or uptitrated. However, none of these options is appropriate in a patient who is already receiving recommended maximal doses of beta-blocker and nitrate therapy and who has a low-normal blood pressure and heart rate.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem and amlodipine) and nitrates are also effective antianginal therapies that can be initiated or uptitrated. However, none of these options is appropriate in a patient who is already receiving recommended maximal doses of beta-blocker and nitrate therapy and who has a low-normal blood pressure and heart rate.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman reports 8 months of substernal chest discomfort that occurs while she is walking her dog up hills or climbing stairs. The discomfort radiates to her jaw and is associated with dyspnea. It resolves with rest or administration of sublingual nitroglycerin and has not increased in frequency. The patient has a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, and an inferior myocardial infarction 9 years ago.
An exercise stress echocardiogram performed 3 months ago showed changes indicative of ischemia that developed when the patient reached 96% of her predicted maximum heart rate. Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography revealed an occluded right coronary artery, with robust collateralization from the left coronary artery. The vessel was not suitable for percutaneous coronary revascularization. The left coronary artery had mild obstructive disease.
On current examination, the patient is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 125/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 56 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 99% while she is breathing ambient air. Her lungs are clear, and her heart sounds are normal.
The patient’s current oral drug regimen comprises aspirin 81 mg daily, lisinopril 40 mg daily, carvedilol 25 mg twice daily, and atorvastatin 80 mg daily. Lipid testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
122
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
68
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
42
≥46


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
80
<150


Which one of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate oral extended-release isosorbide mononitrate 30 mg daily
Initiate oral clopidogrel with a single 600-mg dose, followed by 75 mg daily
Replace atorvastatin with oral rosuvastatin 40 mg daily
Replace carvedilol with extended-release metoprolol 100 mg daily
Conduct outpatient stress testing with a pharmacologic nuclear myocardial perfusion scan

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a patient with chronic stable angina (i.e., typical anginal symptoms precipitated by exertion and relieved with rest or sublingual nitroglycerin), optimization of the antianginal medical regimen is the mainstay of therapy, especially if coronary revascularization might be difficult. The addition of oral isosorbide mononitrate 30 mg daily is the best approach. A calcium-channel blocker is an alternative if the patient is intolerant of treatment with a long-acting nitrate.

Key learning point: In a patient with persistent angina despite use of aspirin, a beta-blocker, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, and a statin, the most appropriate medication to add is a long-acting nitrate or a calcium-channel blocker.

B) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel is appropriate in a patient with an acute coronary syndrome, aspirin intolerance or resistance, or previous percutaneous coronary intervention, but it has not been shown to benefit patients with chronic stable angina.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the patient is already on a high-intensity statin regimen, switching from atorvastatin to rosuvastatin is unwarranted.

D) INCORRECT:

Switching to a different beta-blocker is unlikely to improve symptoms in a patient who is already on optimal doses.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeating an outpatient stress test is not indicated, given that the patient’s symptoms are stable and she is not a candidate for percutaneous coronary revascularization.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman with a 20-year history of rheumatoid arthritis presents to the emergency department for evaluation of epigastric and left-upper-quadrant pain that she describes as gnawing, sharp, intermittent, and nonradiating. Antacids have given her some relief, but the pain has worsened during the past 2 weeks. This morning, she had an acute worsening of symptoms, with sudden-onset nausea, diaphoresis, and one episode of vomiting, while she was walking in the mall. The symptoms improved after she lay down in the ambulance.
The patient’s current medications are omeprazole and methotrexate. She has required many prolonged courses of prednisone during the past 20 years to control her symptoms but is not taking it at this time.
On examination, the patient has a blood pressure of 118/68 mm Hg, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. She appears comfortable and has no symptoms at this time. Her lungs are clear, and cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rate and rhythm without murmurs. She has no tenderness on palpation in the epigastrium. Her extremities are warm, without cyanosis or active synovitis, but she has many chronic structural changes of rheumatoid arthritis, including ulnar deviation of the bilateral metacarpal phalangeal joints, very restricted wrist range of motion, flexion contractures at the bilateral elbows, and significant metatarsal phalangeal joint deformities.
An electrocardiogram documents sinus rhythm with no ST/T-wave abnormalities. An initial complete blood count, liver and electrolyte panel, lipase level, and two sets of cardiac enzyme levels measured 6 hours apart are all negative. A chest radiograph shows chronic interstitial changes. An abdominal CT is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the serum erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram may be reasonable if significant CAD is confirmed, but it is not the best initial test to assess for CAD.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory markers, such as the C-reactive protein level and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, may be elevated because of the patient’s rheumatoid arthritis and would therefore be of little help in diagnosing the cause of her symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient’s pain is unlikely to have arisen from the chest, a chest CT is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

While the results of the stress test are pending, clinicians can reasonably send laboratory testing to assess for other pathologies, such as pancreatitis and pyelonephritis, and can empirically treat for dyspepsia and gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, it would be premature to perform esophagogastroduodenoscopy until CAD has been ruled out.

E) CORRECT:

Individuals with rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune inflammatory diseases have a 1.5- to 2.0-fold increased risk for coronary artery disease (CAD), compared with the general population. Potential contributors to this risk include direct effects of chronic inflammation on vessel walls and coagulation parameters; indirect effects of chronic inflammation on other risk factors for atherosclerosis, such as higher levels of insulin resistance and a more atherogenic lipid profile; and, possibly, direct effects of medications. Glucocorticoids, in particular, are associated with increased cardiovascular mortality and worse heart disease outcomes because of their direct vascular effects and increases in hypertension, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance.

This patient has upper abdominal pain and vomiting, a normal abdominal examination, a normal electrocardiogram (ECG), and a normal abdominal CT, all of which make an intra-abdominal cause for her pain unlikely. Her symptoms are more likely to represent an angina equivalent, given the patient’s rheumatoid arthritis and long-term glucocorticoid use as well as the correlation of her symptoms with exertion. Therefore, CAD should be ruled out. Given that the patient has a normal ECG, normal cardiac biomarkers, and no active symptoms, the most appropriate next step is cardiac stress testing.

Key learning point: When a patient taking chronic glucocorticoids for long-standing rheumatoid arthritis presents with atypical epigastric and left upper quadrant pain, testing should be performed to rule out coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of episodic chest pain that typically occurs when he walks his dog. He has no symptoms at the time of presentation. He has not noticed any changes in the pattern, intensity, or duration of these symptoms during these episodes. The patient has a history of asthma and hypertension. His medications are albuterol as needed and amlodipine. He does not smoke. Physical examination is normal. Electrocardiography shows a sinus rhythm and no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary angiography is a definitive diagnostic tool for identifying coronary artery disease but it is invasive and costly. For this patient with stable cardiac chest pain who is asymptomatic and shows no abnormalities on electrocardiography, guidelines recommend starting with non-invasive tests.

B) INCORRECT:

Troponin (e.g., troponin T) concentrations are measured for the workup of a suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and would be increased in patients with acute myocardial infarction (NSTEMI or STEMI). ACS is extremely unlikely in the absence of acute chest pain or acute chest pain equivalents, change in the characteristic of cardiac chest pain, or new-onset ischemic changes on ECG (e.g., ST elevation, new LBBB, ST depressions, T-wave inversions). Instead, the presentation is more consistent with stable CAD, in which troponin T concentration is of little value in the diagnostic workup.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress testing using adenosine or dipyridamole is contraindicated in patients with reactive airway disease such as asthma because of possible bronchospasm. If pharmacological stress testing is considered, dobutamine should be considered for cardiac stress induction.

D) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery calcium (CAC) scoring using a noncontrast cardiac CT is an appropriate step for risk stratification in patients with a low PTP of CAD. This patient has an intermediate to high PTP of CAD and requires a different test.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with stable chest pain and an intermediate to high PTP of CAD should undergo coronary CT angiography (CCTA) or cardiac stress testing (CST) for further risk stratification and treatment decisions. The goal of CST is to evaluate for stress-induced ischemic changes on ECG or cardiac imaging (stress echocardiography, myocardial perfusion imaging, or cardiac MRI). The stress is created by increasing heart rate and contractility (using exercise or dobutamine) or by inducing a coronary steal phenomenon (using vasodilators such as adenosine or dipyridamole). Reactive airway disease (e.g., asthma) is a contraindication for stress testing using adenosine or dipyridamole.

Key learning point: Exercise stress testing is the preferred initial diagnostic test for stable chest pain in patients with intermediate to high pretest probability of coronary artery disease and no contraindications to exercise.
questions.hint: This patient likely has stable cardiac chest pain (episodic; triggered by physical stress; no change in pattern, intensity, or duration). Stable chest pain in women ≥ 60 years or men ≥ 40 years of age with additional risk factors for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (e.g., hypertension) indicates an intermediate to high pretest probability (PTP) of coronary artery disease (CAD).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with documented coronary artery disease presents with persistent but stable exertional angina despite treatment with atorvastatin and aspirin. The patient’s current blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min with regular rhythm, and his fasting LDL cholesterol level is 65 mg/dL (N < 130). Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-receptor blockers (such as candesartan) are useful adjunctive therapies in patients with coronary disease who have hypertension or left ventricular dysfunction, but they are not anti-anginal agents. Whether they reduce the incidence of myocardial infarction independent of their blood-pressure-lowering effects is controversial.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-acting nitrates (such as isosorbide mononitrate, but not the immediate-release nitrate isosorbide dinitrate) can be considered initially or added if a beta-blocker does not sufficiently control the angina.

C) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors (such as lisinopril) are useful adjunctive therapies in patients with coronary disease who have hypertension or left ventricular dysfunction, but they are not anti-anginal agents. Whether they reduce the incidence of myocardial infarction independent of their blood-pressure-lowering effects is controversial.

D) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel is an antiplatelet agent and does not have antianginal properties.

E) CORRECT:

A beta-blocker is one of the first-line therapeutic agents for patients with symptomatic coronary artery disease, especially those with concomitant hypertension. Beta-blockers reduce myocardial oxygen demand by decreasing blood pressure, heart rate, and myocardial contractility.

Key learning point: In addition to aspirin and a statin, the type of medication routinely recommended for a patient with symptomatic coronary artery disease is a beta-blocker.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 5-month history of episodic chest pain that is unrelated to exercise or rest and does not radiate. The episodes typically last less than 15 minutes and lead to feelings of anxiety. She has not had dyspnea, cough, or lightheadedness. She has no history of serious illness. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography shows normal sinus rhythm. At this visit, which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for coronary artery disease in this patient?

choices.text: No further testing at this visit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A pharmacological cardiac stress test (e.g., regadenoson cardiac MRI) is an option for cardiac stress testing in patients with an intermediate or high PTP of CAD. This patient has a low PTP of CAD.

B) INCORRECT:

A pharmacological cardiac stress test (e.g., dobutamine stress echocardiography) is an option for cardiac stress testing in patients with an intermediate or high PTP of CAD. This patient has a low PTP of CAD.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with a low PTP of CAD, a shared decision-making approach that takes patient preferences, cost, and available resources at the setting of the care into consideration is recommended.
